title: 1. Getting Started
text:
Rust

A language empowering everyone to build reliable and efficient software.


Let‚Äôs get started.
Rust says it‚Äôs a ‚Äòlanguage empowering ‚Ä¶‚Äô The key words that stick out for me are ‚Äòreliable‚Äô and ‚Äòefficient.‚Äô
If you‚Äôre like me, those are the main selling points you‚Äôve heard related to rust. Rust is efficient, both in terms of run time and development time. And Rust is reliable, eliminating bugs related to memory management that come up in languages like C.
By the end of this book, we should have an idea of how well Rust holds up to those statements.

title: 1. Getting Started
text:
Set up

Install Rust
Choose an editor
Install extensions


I assume you can install Rust but if you have issues we can help shortly.
It‚Äôs likely many of us have only used R and RStudio. If that‚Äôs the case, I want to point out some differences you‚Äôll encounter.
Both R and RStudio come with everything you need to write R code. However, with other languges and editors, you often need to install tools specific to that language. For example, language servers, debuggers, and package managers. You most definitely want to install the Rust tooling for whatever editor you use.
If you aren‚Äôt sure, I recommend using Visual Studio Code with the rust-analyzer extension. You will also need an extension with debugging support. You can find a link in the rust-analyzer extension. Again, if you need help with this, we can get to that shortly.

title: 1. Getting Started
text:
Hello, World
fn main() {
    println!("Hello, world!");
}

fn main() is required in main.rs
The ! in println! means macro
The ; is required


This is the obligatory hello world. Since this is a simple program, it‚Äôs clear what‚Äôs going on.
But there are some details worth pointing out.
Every rust program has a main.rs file with a main function in it. This is the entrypoint to the program, the first thing that get‚Äôs run.
The ! in println! means println is a macro. A macro is sort of like a function. That‚Äôs a sufficient understanding for now. We‚Äôll get to the details of what a macro is later in the book.
Lastly, note the ; which indicated the end of an expression. This is generally required for every statement you write.

title: 1. Getting Started
text:
Compile and run
rustc main.rs
./main

Rust is a compiled language so we have to run the compiler rustc first.
If you‚Äôve never used a compiled language before, compiling is the process of translating the Rust code you write into a language the computer can read. With interpreted languages like R or Python, this translation happens on the fly. But with a compiled language, you have to translate the program before it can run.
Once compiled, you‚Äôll have an executable file that you can now run. On Mac/Linux, it will be main. On Windows, it will be main.exe.

title: 1. Getting Started
text:
Cargo
[package]
name = "hello_cargo"
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2021"

[dependencies]

Unlike R, where installing dependencies is built into the language, Rust has a separate program for this called cargo. With cargo, you define your dependencies, among other things, in a TOML file.

title: 1. Getting Started
text:
Cargo




cargo new project_name
Cargo.toml
cargo.lock



project_name/.Rproj
DESCRIPTION
renv.lock




More than installing dependencies though, cargo helps you manage your Rust projects. It let‚Äôs you create projects, install dependencies, compile, and run your project.
A cargo project is like an RStudio project.
Cargo.toml is like DESCRIPTION in an R package.
And cargo tracks dependency versions with cargo.lock, which is like renv.lock.

title: 1. Getting Started

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Topics Covered:


Data Types

Scalar
Compound

Variables, Mutability, Constants, and Shadowing
Functions and Control Flow
Error Handling

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Integers





Length
Signed
Unsigned




8-bit
i8
u8


16-bit
i16
u16


32-bit
i32
u32


64-bit
i64
u64


128-bit
i128
u128


arch
isize
usize






Signed variants can store numbers from -(2n - 1) to 2n - 1¬†- 1 inclusive

i8: -(27) to 27¬†- 1, which equals -128 to 127.
u8: 0- 2n - 1, that is 0 to 28¬†- 1, which equals 0 to 255

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Integer overflow
Rust uses two‚Äôs complement wrapping to handle integer overflow silently. However, it offers explicit ways to manage overflow:

wrapping_* methods: Always wrap values (e.g., wrapping_add).
checked_* methods: Return None if overflow occurs.
overflowing_* methods: Return the result along with a boolean indicating overflow.
saturating_* methods: Clamp the result to the type‚Äôs minimum or maximum value.

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Floating-Point Numbers
Types: f32 and f64 (primitive types)
  let pi: f64 = 3.14159;


All floating-point types are signed.
f32: single-precision float
f64: double precision float

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Booleans and Characters
Boolean: bool
  let flag = true;
Character: char 1
  let emoji = 'üòª';


char¬†type is four bytes in size and represents a Unicode Scalar Value.
It can represent more than just ASCII





Note that we specify¬†char¬†literals with single quotes, as opposed to string literals, which use double quotes.

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Tuples
Group values of different types:
  let tup: (i32, f64, u8) = (500, 6.4, 1);
  let (x, y, z) = tup; // Destructuring

Tuples have a fixed length.

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Initializing arrays
  let a = [3; 5]; // [3, 3, 3, 3, 3]
Short-hand:


value of elements; then number of elements


let a = [3; 5];

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Immutable Variables
Variables in Rust are immutable by default:
  let x = 5;
  x = 6; // Error: Cannot assign to immutable variable

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Making Variables Mutable
Use the mut keyword to make variables mutable:
  let mut y = 10;
  y += 5; // Now valid because `y` is mutable

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Constants
Declared with const and are always immutable:
  const MAX_SCORE: u32 = 100_000;


Must always be annotated with a type
Can be declared in global or function scope
Cannot be computed at runtime

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Differences between mut and Shadowing




mut
shadowing




Type
Same type
Can change type (use of let)


Use of let
When first declared
All instances of variable use

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
section: Using if in a let Statement

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Integer Overflow

Debug mode: Panics on overflow.
Release mode: Uses two‚Äôs complement wrapping.

wrapping_* methods: Always wrap values (e.g., wrapping_add).
checked_* methods: Return None if overflow occurs.
overflowing_* methods: Return the result along with a boolean indicating overflow.
saturating_* methods: Clamp the result to the type‚Äôs minimum or maximum value.

title: 3. Common Programming Concepts
3. Common Programming Concepts
text:
Feature
Rust
R
Python
C/C++




Arrays
Fixed-size, homogeneous types, defined as [T; N].
Homogeneous data, multidimensional (using array()).
Homogeneous data, implemented via NumPy (numpy.array).
Fixed-size, homogeneous, defined as T array[N].


Vectors
A growable collection with Vec<T>.
1D array, typically with c() or vector().
Lists mimic vectors, but for true vector operations, use NumPy arrays.
No native vector, use std::vector from the Standard Library (C++).


Tuples
Fixed-length, immutable collection: (i32, f64).
Not commonly used, lists behave like tuples.
Immutable, ordered sequence: (1, 2, "text").
Use std::tuple (C++17+) or structures.


Matrices
Not native; use nested Vec<Vec<T>> or external libraries like nalgebra.
2D structure (matrix()). Can extend to 3D with array().
Implemented with NumPy as 2D arrays: numpy.matrix or numpy.array.
2D arrays as T matrix[rows][cols] or use libraries like Eigen in C++.


Mutability
Vectors (Vec<T>) are mutable; tuples are immutable.
Vectors are mutable; matrices can be altered in-place.
Lists and arrays are mutable; tuples are immutable.
Arrays and vectors (std::vector) are mutable. Tuples are immutable in C++17+.


Indexing
0-based indexing (e.g., x[0]).
1-based indexing (e.g., x[1]).
0-based indexing (e.g., x[0]).
0-based indexing (e.g., x[0]).


Size Flexibility
Arrays are fixed, vectors grow dynamically.
Vectors and lists are dynamic. Arrays and matrices have fixed sizes.
Lists and NumPy arrays are dynamic; tuples are fixed size.
Arrays are fixed; std::vector is dynamic.



A contiguous mutable array type, written as¬†Vec<T>, short for ‚Äòvector‚Äô.

title: 5. Using Structs to Structure Related Data

Defining Structs
struct User {
    active: bool,
    username: String,
    email: String,
    sign_in_count: u64,
}

Structs are similar to tuples, but with named parts
Similar to R named lists, key : value pairs.
Defines a new type

title: 5. Using Structs to Structure Related Data
text:
Ownership of Struct Data

Examples so far used owned data (e.g.¬†String)
Ensures fields are valid as long as the struct is valid.
Structs can store references, but this requires explicitly specifying lifetimes to ensure they remain valid (discussed in Chapter 10).

Self

&self is shorthand for self : &Self
Self is shorthand for the object type. (Rectangle)
&self or &mut self, borrowing, is most common
using just self and taking ownership is rare.

title: 2. Programming a Guessing Game
text:
Create the new Project
$ cargo new guessing_game
$ cd guessing_game

recall, cargo is Rust‚Äôs package manager and build tool
cargo new creates a new project with the given name
by default, this creates a ‚ÄúHello World‚Äù program

title: 2. Programming a Guessing Game
text:
Compile and run it
$ cargo run

cargo run both compiles and runs the project
you should see ‚ÄúHello, world!‚Äù output to your console
you can also just compile with cargo build

title: 2. Programming a Guessing Game
text:
Storing Values with Variables
let mut guess = String::new();

add this to the main function in src/main.rs
use let to create variables
variables are immutable by default
use let mut for mutable variable

title: 2. Programming a Guessing Game
2. Programming a Guessing Game
text:
Handling Potential Failure with Result
io::stdin()
    .read_line(&mut guess)
    .expect("Failed to read line");

read_line returns a Result type (either Ok or Err)
use .expect() to handle errors and crash if an error occurs

title: 2. Programming a Guessing Game
text:
Printing Values with println!
println!("You guessed: {guess}");

use println! with placeholders ({}) for formatted output
combines user input and text in one statement

title: 2. Programming a Guessing Game
text:
Testing the First Part
$ cargo run

program now accepts input and prints the guess
test by entering values to see the output

title: 2. Programming a Guessing Game
2. Programming a Guessing Game
section: Using a Crate to Get More Functionality
text:
Using a Crate to Get More Functionality
[dependencies]
rand = "0.8.5"

add the rand crate to Cargo.toml under [dependencies]
cargo build will fetch and compile external dependencies
you can also use cargo add to add dependencies

e.g.¬†cargo add rand

title: 2. Programming a Guessing Game
2. Programming a Guessing Game
section: Matching the Guess to the Secret Number

title: 2. Programming a Guessing Game
section: Parsing a String into a Number
text:
Parsing a String into a Number
let guess: u32 = guess.trim().parse().expect("Please type a number!");

guess is a string, but we want to compare it to an integer
use trim() to remove unexpected whitespace from the string
use parse() to convert the string to an integer
this code should now compile

title: 2. Programming a Guessing Game
2. Programming a Guessing Game
2. Programming a Guessing Game
2. Programming a Guessing Game
Welcome
text:
This is a companion for the book The Rust Programming Language by Steve Klabnik and Carol Nichols, with contributions from the Rust Community (copyright 2024).
Each chapter title to the left is a link to a slide deck.

These slides are being developed by this club.
Each deck will open in its own tab.
You may want to type ‚Äús‚Äù at the start of each deck to open the speaker notes.
Join the Data Science Learning Community to participate in the discussion!

We follow the Data Science Learning Community Code of Conduct.

title: Club Meetings
text:
Book club meetings

Volunteer leads discussion of a chapter

This is the best way to learn the material.

Presentations:

Review of material
Questions you have
Maybe live demo

More info about editing: this github repo.
Recorded, available on the Data Science Learning Community YouTube Channel (DSLC.video).
Sign up to present


In case this is your first book club here, this is how things work. We‚Äôll meet weekly and have a presentation followed by a discussion.
We‚Äôre working through this book collaboratively so everyone is encouraged to present a session or two. Please have a look at the schedule ASAP. We need presenters for the next 2 weeks.

title: Club Meetings
text:
Pace

Goal: 1 chapter/week
Ok to split overwhelming chapters
Ok to combine short chapters
Meet every week except holidays, etc

Ideally can discuss even if presenter unavailable

Monday at 2:00 pm PST (2100 GMT)


The schedule will be consistent for the most part but if we need to make adjustments everyone will be notified well ahead of time. For example, we will most likely meet for one of the scheduled holiday breaks or combine 2 chapters to one week. Daylight savings in the spring comes right at the end of schedule and is particularly gnarly this year I‚Äôd like to finish before then.

title: Club Meetings
text:
Learning objectives (LOs)

Students who study with LOs in mind retain more.
Tips:

‚ÄúAfter today‚Äôs session, you will be able to‚Ä¶‚Äù
Very roughly 1 per section.



When writing your presentation it can help to define learning objectives. This can help you identify the key points of the chapter, which also helps everyone else. It‚Äôs not strictly required though so don‚Äôt stress about it.
